skills.name: Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a number line
List all possible solutions to a linear inequality
Form inequalities from situations described in words

explanations.A: Not quite. The line stops at 0 here, but we want all numbers bigger than -5, including the positive ones
explanations.B: This would be representing numbers less than -5, double check the inequality in the question.
explanations.C: The line is above all numbers that are greater than -5, and the arrow shows this line will continue over all the other numbers that will be further up the number line. Therefore it is matching the inequality in the question.
explanations.D: Almost. The dot on the end of the line is showing us that it stops at 5, but we want to include all numbers greater than -5. How could we show this on the diagram?

explanations.A: Almost. The dot on the end of the line is showing us that it stops at -10, but we want to include all numbers less than 5. How could we show this on the diagram?
explanations.B: Not quite. The line stops at 0 here, but we want all numbers less than 5, including the negative ones
explanations.C: This would be representing numbers greater than 5, double check the inequality in the question.
explanations.D: The line is above all numbers that are less than 5, and the arrow shows this line will continue over all the other numbers that will be further down the number line. Therefore it is matching the inequality in the question.

explanations.A: You may believe algebra has only one solution, but here we have an inequality. Think about how many numbers you could put in place of 洧논 that would make the inequality true.
explanations.B: I think you have assumed we can only put in positive whole numbers. Remember 洧논 can be any number, positive or negative, whole or fractional, as long as it is less than 3.
explanations.C: I think you have assumed we can only put in positive whole numbers and 0. Remember 洧논 can be any number, positive or negative, whole or fractional, as long as it is less than 3.
explanations.D: There are infinitely many numbers that are less than 3. For example 2, -1/3, -999.43 etc.

explanations.A: There are infinitely many numbers that are greater than -10. For example 2, -1/3, 999.43 etc.
explanations.B: I think you have assumed we can only put in whole numbers up to 0 . Remember 洧논 can be any number, positive or negative, whole or fractional, as long as it is greater than -10.
explanations.C: You may believe algebra has only one solution, but here we have an inequality. Think about how many numbers you could put in place of 洧논 that would make the inequality true.
explanations.D: I think you have assumed we can only put in whole numbers up to and including 0 . Remember 洧논 can be any number, positive or negative, whole or fractional, as long as it is greater than -10.

explanations.A: This would be true if you had to be exactly 4 ft tall. How could we show that only OVER 4 ft is allowed?
explanations.B: Here we have to have a height over 4 ft, so h has to be greater than 4, so h > 4.
explanations.C: This would mean that heights of 3 and a half ft would be allowed on the ride, which isn't true. How can we make sure only heights OVER 4 ft are included?
explanations.D: Almost, but this is saying the height is less than 4 ft.

explanations.A: This would mean that heights of 4 and a half ft would not be allowed on the ride, which isn't true. How can we make sure all heights under 5 ft are included?
explanations.B: Here we have to have a height under 5 ft, so h has to be less than 5, so h < 5.
explanations.C: This would be true if you had to be exactly 5 ft tall. How could we show only under 5 ft is allowed?
explanations.D: Almost, but this is saying the height is more than 5 ft.

explanations.A: The angle 洧논 has to be less than 180, so 洧논 < 180
explanations.B: I think you have put in 3洧논 as there are 3 angles in a triangle. We are told about each angle, 洧논, so how would we express that each angle is less than 180?
explanations.C: Almost, but this is saying the angle has to be greater than 180.
explanations.D: Almost, but this is saying the angle is allowed to be 180 exactly, but it has to be less than that.

explanations.A: Almost, but this is saying the angle has to be less than 90.
explanations.B: I think you have put in 4y as there are more than 4 sides specified in the question. We are told about each angle, y, so how would we express that each angle is greater than 90?
explanations.C: I think you have written the inequality for the number of sides. We want the inequality to be about the size of the angle.
explanations.D: Each angle y has to be bigger than 90, so y > 90.

explanations.A: This is saying that each side length needs to be bigger than 100, but that would give perimeters of over 400. How can we find out one side if we know the perimeter is 100?
explanations.B: Almost, but this is saying that the side lengths are less than 25. Would this give a perimeter greater than 100?
explanations.C: I think you have confused area and perimeter. Remember the perimeter is the distance around the outside of the shape.
explanations.D: 100 / 4 = 25, so each side length has to be bigger than 25. That is l > 25.

explanations.A: I think you have confused area and perimeter. Remember the perimeter is the distance around the outside of the shape.
explanations.B: 64 / 4 = 16, so each side length has to be less than 16. That is l < 16.
explanations.C: This is saying that each side length needs to be greater than 64, and that would give perimeters of more than 256. How can we find out one side if we know the perimeter is 64?
explanations.D: Almost, but this is saying that the side lengths are greater than 16. Would this give a perimeter less than 64?
